fullProgramDescription: The Pharmacological Chemistry major is designed for students who wish to pursue a career in the pharmaceutical industry or a related field. The program provides a strong foundation in chemistry, biochemistry, and pharmacology, as well as a comprehensive understanding of the principles and practices of pharmacological chemistry.
shortProgramDescription: The Pharmacological Chemistry B.S. program provides students with a comprehensive education in chemistry, biochemistry, and pharmacology, preparing them for careers in the pharmaceutical industry or related fields.
classHighlights: The program requires a series of core chemistry courses, including CHEM131, CHEM132, CHEM143, and CHEM152, which provide a foundation in general, organic, and biological chemistry.
Biochemistry courses, including BICD100 and BICD110, provide a comprehensive understanding of the principles of biochemistry and its application to pharmacological chemistry.
Pharmacology courses, including PHAR100 and PHAR110, provide a detailed understanding of the principles of pharmacology and its application to the development of new therapeutic agents.

Additional required courses include MATH10A, MATH10B, and MATH20A, which provide a foundation in mathematical principles, as well as PHYS1A and PHYS1B, which provide a foundation in physical principles.

Electives in pharmacological chemistry, including PHAR121 and PHAR122, allow students to explore advanced topics in the field and gain a deeper understanding of the principles and practices of pharmacological chemistry.
learningOutcomes: Apply the principles of chemistry, biochemistry, and pharmacology to the development of new therapeutic agents.
Understand the mechanisms of action of pharmacological agents and their interactions with biological systems.
Analyze the pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic properties of therapeutic agents.
Design and conduct experiments to investigate the properties of pharmacological agents.
Communicate complex scientific information effectively in written and oral form.
